definition: to guard/to defend/to keep watch/to abide by the law/to observe (rules or ritual)/nearby/adjoining
(idiom) to continue in the same old rut/diehard conservative attitudes

sentences.english: Your counter-offer is much more modest tha free mine.
sentences.chinese: 你們的還盤比我的要守舊得多。

sentences.english: The English are, as often as not, labeled conservative. Obviously this label is prejudiced.
sentences.chinese: 英國人常常被回類爲守舊型，顯然這一回類帶有成見。

sentences.english: New Year celebrations. These conservative who advocates reform of the big mockery.
sentences.chinese: 主張鼎新的人對於這些守舊者的作法大加嘲搞。

sentences.english: We will equip Jordan, meanwhile, Jordan with a keyboard or an old-school pen.
sentences.chinese: 同時，用一個鍵盤，或守舊派鋼筆來裝備。

sentences.english: EXAMPLE: The boss was an old fuddy-duddy who did not allow dancing at company parties.
sentences.chinese: 老闆思想守舊，不準在公司聚會上跳舞。

sentences.english: This is not a question of being more liberal or more conservative.
sentences.chinese: 這個問題無關自由開放還是因循守舊。

sentences.english: Conservatives are worried about the growing power of the state.
sentences.chinese: 守舊派擔憂國家權力的增長。

sentences.english: So why not start the siege on the old guard of literary journals and magazines?
sentences.chinese: 所以爲什麼不開始圍攻守舊的文學期刊雜誌呢？

sentences.english: And others simply clung to old party traditions.
sentences.chinese: 還有一些人則墨守舊黨派的傳統。

sentences.english: I'm a bit of an old fogy.
sentences.chinese: 我更像是一個守舊的人。

sentences.english: But I would probably have to go old school.
sentences.chinese: 但我也可能是個守舊派。

sentences.english: London doesn't seem as hidebound by tradition as some of the other European cities.
sentences.chinese: 不像其他歐洲城市，倫敦並不因傳統而守舊。

sentences.english: Yet France’s Socialist Party also stands out as Europe’s most unreconstructed.
sentences.chinese: 然而，法國的社會黨在歐洲也是出了名的頑固守舊。

sentences.english: I'm too old-fashioned to be that broad-minded.
sentences.chinese: 我很守舊不會那樣開明。

sentences.english: He thought i was a square when i said i loved the truth .
sentences.chinese: 當我說我熱愛真理，他認爲我是個古板守舊的老頑固。

definition: to confuse one thing with another (idiom); to muddle
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
to make a show of being original or unconventional (idiom)
to rebel against orthodoxy/to depart from established practices
